France bans large indoor gatherings with more than 5000 attendees. Measures announced after an emergency cabinet meeting also include the cancellation of the Paris half-marathon which was to be held on Sunday. Among the events affected by the prohibition of large indoor gatherings is Paris's annual agricultural fair. Its final day, which was scheduled for Sunday, has been cancelled.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200625172238/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-51690657    The government has also banned all public gatherings in the Oise district north of Paris and in La Balme-de-Sillingy, a town in the French Alps where cases have been reported. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-health-france/france-bans-gatherings-of-more-than-5000-due-to-coronavirus-idUSKBN20N0MD

Generally, indoor gatherings of over 5000 people are banned in France.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200813095342/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-51690657  In the worst hit area of north Paris, all pubic gatherings are banned, hence the 4T coding instead of 1G. "The government has also banned all public gatherings in the Oise district north of Paris and in La Balme-de-Sillingy, a town in the French Alps where cases have been reported." https://web.archive.org/web/20200813095405/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-health-france/france-bans-gatherings-of-more-than-5000-due-to-coronavirus-idUSKBN20N0MD  "In the department of Oise, the main epidemic center, and in the town of La Balme-de-Sillingy, in Haute-Savoie, all public gatherings - including masses - are prohibited "until further notice"." https://web.archive.org/web/20200813095458/https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2020/02/29/coronavirus-le-gouvernement-decide-l-interdiction-des-rassemblements-de-plus-de-5-000-personnes-en-milieu-confine-et-de-certains-autres-en-milieu-ouvert-dont-le-semi-marathon-de-paris_6031356_823448.html An excellent summary can be found at: http://web.archive.org/web/20201208203331/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/les-actions-du-gouvernement

"Public transport in built-up areas will be maintained to allow the French to carry out the strictly necessary trips," explained Elisabeth Borne. Longer distance transport between urban areas - by train, coach and plane - will be progressively reduced in order to limit the spread of the virus on national territory. But everyone can return to their home, there will be no sudden stop and no full stop.    la ministre de la transition écologique et solidaire, Elisabeth Borne, et le secrétaire d’Etat aux transports, Jean-Baptiste Djebbari, ont détaillé, dimanche matin, plusieurs mesures d’adaptation à cette nouvelle donne. « Les transports en commun en agglomération seront maintenus pour permettre aux Français d’accomplir les déplacements strictement nécessaires, a expliqué Elisabeth Borne. Les transports de plus longue distance entre les agglomérations – par train, car et avion – seront progressivement réduits afin de limiter la propagation du virus sur le territoire national. Mais tout le monde pourra retourner vers son domicile, il n’y aura pas d’arrêt brutal et pas d’arrêt complet. » https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.lemonde.fr/economie/article/2020/03/16/a-travers-l-hexagone-les-transports-en-mode-virus_6033189_3234.html    “We must absolutely limit movement, meetings and contacts,” French prime minister Edouard Philippe said on Saturday evening. Food shops, tobacconists, banks and public transport will remain open, he said.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200425101434/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/14/france-closes-non-essential-public-spaces-due-to-coronavirus      Long-distance transport (trains, buses, planes) will be "gradually reduced". There will be around 80% of traffic on the metro. http://web.archive.org/web/20200425102359/https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/Covid-19-in-France-Transport-trains-buses-planes-SNCF-gradually-reduced-says-transport-minister

"On Saturday evening, as many French people were out for dinner or a drink with their friends, Prime Minister Edouard Philippe announced that, as of midnight, the government would close down all “non-essential commercial activity” in a bid to fight the rapid spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) in the country.  On Sunday morning, in an official decree, the French health ministry detailed what that would mean, followed up with a second decree Monday morning providing further clarification on the types of businesses affected by the ban, which is set to last until at least April 15th. They include: conference rooms, meeting rooms, show rooms or other rooms where several people gather at the same time; shopping centres, malls; restaurants and bars; night clubs, gaming rooms; libraries and research centres; exhibition halls; gyms and other sports venues; museums; early learning, teaching and training centres; leisure centres without accommodation; marquees, tents and outdoor establishments"  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210701171843/https://www.thelocal.fr/20200315/france-coronavirus-lockdownwhats-closed-and-whats-open-in-france-following-the-new-coronavirus-restrictions/

"After weeks of official statements saying it was not necessary to wear a mask unless you were sick or worked in the medical profession, France's Académie Nationale de Médecine (Academy of Medicine) announced Friday that a mask should be compulsory during outings both during and after the current lockdown.   The French government quickly followed with an announcement that the manufacture of non-medical "alternative" masks to be used by the public would be ramped up and, the next day, said it had ordered 2 billion face masks from China.  The reversal came after media reports – notably by investigative news site Mediapart and state-run TV France 2 – that the government’s early insistence that face masks were not useful was, in fact, prompted by a shortage of them.  (...) But even before that, the French government was giving mixed signals. While officially maintaining that face masks were unnecessary for people without symptoms or who are not caring for coronavirus sufferers, President Emmanuel Macron announced plans to rapidly increase France’s production." Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200429005849/https://www.euronews.com/2020/04/20/coronavirus-and-the-elderly-what-s-life-inside-a-french-retirement-home-amid-covid-19-pand    Note: Code remains unchanged because even though the government has announced the easing of restrictions regarding visits to nursing homes, the confinement as been extended and requires that the elderly stay at home (in these cases, the most stringent policy is coded).

France's Director General of Health Jérôme Salomon said: "We encourage the general public, if they so wish, to wear (...) these alternative masks which are being produced." Masks are not compulsory yet, but recommmended, hence 1G.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200916054944/https://www.thelocal.fr/20200406/mask-or-no-mask-what-is-the-official-coronavirus-advice-in-france

France is to have “brigades” of people who will trace contacts of people who test positive for Covid-19 after confinement ends, to help contain further spread of the virus. "Prime minister Edouard Philippe made the announcement as part of his speech on Tuesday April 28. He said: “[We want to] protect, test, isolate. In each department, we will have brigades whose job it is to compile a list of contacts, and to call them, to invite them to be tested, telling them where to go for a test, and then to check that these tests have indeed been done.”" [https://web.archive.org/web/20200514043914/https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/Covid-19-coronavirus-contact-tracing-brigades-in-France-What-we-know-so-far]

'France to pledge 500 million euros for global coronavirus vaccine hunt', (Monday 4th May 2020).  https://uk.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-eu-france/macron-france-to-pledge-500-million-euros-for-global-coronavirus-vaccine-hunt-idUKKBN22G1PF

Schools start to reopen. "To meet the fears of teachers and families, the thousands of nursery and primary schools, which reopen, will be subject to a strict health protocol, to avoid any further outbreak of the epidemic." [https://web.archive.org/web/20200520143429/https://www.france24.com/fr/20200512-le-d%C3%A9confinement-continue-en-france-avec-la-r%C3%A9ouverture-des-%C3%A9coles]

Some shops are re-opening, hairdressers, beauty salons, markets to name a few: https://web.archive.org/web/20200722152406/https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/France-deconfinement-May-11-What-is-allowed-or-not-allowed-parks-beaches-schools-bars-restaurants-going-out-travel-transport

The décret of May 11 stipulates that gatherings of more than 10 people are forbidden (except for professional reasons).  "Tout rassemblement, réunion ou activité à un titre autre que professionnel sur la voie publique ou dans un lieu public, mettant en présence de manière simultanée plus de dix personnes, est interdit sur l'ensemble du territoire de la République".  https://web.archive.org/web/20200916095903/https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/jorf/id/JORFTEXT000041858681

As part of France's measures to lift lockdown, "Public transport between regions will also be reduced to ensure people comply and advanced reservation will be compulsory.  In the Paris metro, capacity will be reduced to about 70 percent for at least three weeks after May 11. Philippe says only "one seat out of two" will be in use and platforms will be marked to encourage social distancing and the flow of passengers will be reduced for rush hour."  [https://web.archive.org/web/20200520113256/https://www.france24.com/en/20200429-key-points-of-france-s-strategy-for-lifting-its-nationwide-covid-19-lockdown]

People who can work from home are recommended to do so. [https://web.archive.org/web/20200520113256/https://www.france24.com/en/20200429-key-points-of-france-s-strategy-for-lifting-its-nationwide-covid-19-lockdown]

You can travel up to a maximum of 100km from your home address: http://web.archive.org/web/20201209101806/https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/France-deconfinement-May-11-What-is-allowed-or-not-allowed-parks-beaches-schools-bars-restaurants-going-out-travel-transport

After May 11, 2020, anyone with symptoms or who has been exposed to a risk of contamination will be tested.   "La doctrine scientifique fondant la stratégie nationale de dépistage virologique applicable à  compter du 11 mai 2020 consiste à dépister toute personne présentant des symptômes ou ayant  été exposée à un risque de contamination."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200524201028/https://www.gouvernement.fr/sites/default/files/rapport_jean_castex_-_preparation_de_la_sortie_du_confinement.pdf

May 11 marks the beginning of a gradual deconfinement. Monitoring of all the indicators is underway (the rate of new cases in the population over a period of seven days, the hospital capacities in intensive care remain saturated, the local system of tests and detection of contact cases is not sufficiently ready).   This phase will run until June 2.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200524220240/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/les-actions-du-gouvernement

After May 11, masks are mandatory in public transport.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200916092858/https://www.liberation.fr/direct/element/transports-en-commun-le-port-du-masque-obligatoire-a-partir-du-11-mai_112895/  Recommended indoor.

April 20 - "France began lifting its coronavirus ban on family visits to nursing homes on Monday (...)   After more than a month in seclusion, France’s 7,000 care homes for the elderly were told they could resume visits from family members starting on Monday but under strict conditions to ensure the safety of their residents. With the elderly particularly vulnerable to Covid-19, all physical contact will remain strictly barred (...) Announcing the new measures a day earlier, Health Minister Olivier Véran said visits would be limited to two family members per resident, and would only begin once safety measures were in place. Véran assured the public that the country’s care homes had finally received the necessary protective gear after weeks of desperate shortages."  Source: https://archive.vn/sJu31

The government launched a plan to support the sectors of tourism, sports and culture: 3 billion euros. https://web.archive.org/web/20200607122854/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/plan-soutien-secteur-tourisme

In most regions, restrictions on work have been lifted, but the government recommends working remotely wherever possible. In regions with local outbreaks, stricter policies may remain in place.     https://archive.vn/3Dxvq

Banks are asked by the government to help out their clients, provide solutions (for instance, postponing loan repayments); but since the government ensures that the population's purchasing power does not lower, there are no official measures with regards to freezing households' financial obligations households (these measures only apply to companies). https://web.archive.org/web/20200608212857/https://point-banque.fr/2020/03/20/la-banque-de-france-exclut-tout-report-des-echeances-bancaires-pour-les-particuliers/
The government launched a plan to support the car industry. 8 billion euros. https://web.archive.org/web/20200607123510/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/plan-soutien-filiere-automobile

In Ile-de-France, during peak hours, access to public transport is reserved for people with a travel certificate from their employer or a certificate justifying a specific reason ( list of reasons on the PRIF website ). https://web.archive.org/web/20200611204115/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/les-actions-du-gouvernement

As of 2nd June, France began the second stage of deconfinement. There are no longer any stay at home requirements, but working from home is still recommended when possible, and possible outdoor activities are specific and limited to strict social distancing guidelines, so this is still coded as a recommendation to stay home during this 'gradual easing back'.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200611204115/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/les-actions-du-gouvernement

Travel to overseas territories is limited to people who can "justify an overriding health, family or professional reason."  "On your arrival in Guadeloupe, Guyana, Reunion, Martinique, Saint-Martin, Saint-Barthélemy and Saint-Pierre-et-Miquelon, you are invited to remain isolated for 14 days, possibly in an accommodation."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200611204115/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/les-actions-du-gouvernement

Entry into the territory for travelers from countries outside the European area is prohibited and entry into the territory from the European area is subject to restrictions, until further notice  https://web.archive.org/web/20200611204115/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/les-actions-du-gouvernement

" France is rolling out an official coronavirus contact-tracing app aimed at containing fresh outbreaks as lockdown restrictions gradually ease, becoming the first major European country to deploy the smartphone technology amid simmering debate over privacy fears.  The French will be able to download the StopCovid app on their Google Android devices and Apple iPhones starting Tuesday, the same day they'll once again be allowed to go to restaurants and cafes, parks and beaches and museums and monuments.  (...) Authorities hope the app can help manage virus flare-ups as they reopen the economy in France, which has been living under some of Europe's tightest restrictions since it became one of the countries hardest hit by the pandemic, with nearly 29,000 deaths."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210702140739/https://www.france24.com/en/20200602-france-rolls-out-covid-19-tracing-app-amid-privacy-debate  Note: No evidence of comprehensive MANUAL comprehensive contact tracing was found.

"The French health ministry has allowed family members to visit ageing relatives in nursing homes as of Friday, providing hygiene rules are respected (...) Family visits will be able to resume "if conditions are right", according to a statement issued by the French health ministry on Monday (...) Some care homes had already begun allowing visits from 20 April, to relieve isolation, but these were restricted to two family members, with no physical contact. Under the revised rules, more than two people can visit if in an outdoor setting, and two people maximum per room. Children will be allowed to visit as long as they wear masks. Visits will no longer be monitored by staff members, as was previously required. "Hand washing, social distancing, wearing a mask will be mandatory for all visitors," the ministry statement said."  Note: Code remains unchanged since there are still for e.g. restrictions on the number of visitors per room, location of the visit etc  Source: https://archive.vn/bcgB3#selection-1295.0-1299.58

Officially, gatherings of more than 5000 are forbidden until October 30.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915145022/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus  Rallies, although they are officially forbidden, are tolerated in the wake of George Floyd's murder, said the Minister Christophe Castaner.  /web/20200915144206/https://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/societe/rassemblements-toleres-contre-les-violences-policieres-colere-de-la-droite-et-du-rn_2127811.html  Similarly, the "Fête de la Musique" festivities are officially cancelled, but there is some lack of compliance regarding gatherings in public and in private.

Following the manifestations (protests/demonstrations) in France, the Conseil d'Etat suspends the restriction on public gatherings of 10 people or more, if it is for the purpose of manifesting. Manifestations can gather up to 5000 people. However, the general prohibition on private and public gatherings of more than 10 people remains.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200916100611/https://www.liberation.fr/france/2020/06/13/le-conseil-d-etat-suspend-l-interdiction-des-rassemblements-de-plus-de-dix-personnes_1791179
French borders with other EU states are now open.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200625232503/https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travel to the French overseas territories remains restricted. 'Entry into French Guiana and Mayotte is only allowed for emergency family or work reasons, given that the virus is still actively circulating in these territories. Travellers arriving in these territories will be subject to strict 14-day quarantine measures.' Travelers to other overseas territories are subject to mandatory testing or quarantine.     https://archive.vn/WypkZ

President Macron has announced the reopening of nurseries, schools, and colleges in metropolitan France and overseas, starting on June 22nd.    In schools and colleges, physical distance regulations have been eased. Instead of the required 4m2 per pupil, a one-metre distance must be observed between the teacher and pupils (and between pupils themselves) in classrooms and confined spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200713070356/https://www.vie-publique.fr/discours/274578-emmanuel-macron-14062020-covid-19

On 22nd June, the next phase of deconfiment was entered, with the whole of France being declared a "green zone" with little to no workplace closures (except for discotheques and fair grounds). Advice is as following: Working from home must be preferred whenever possible.    If you cannot work from home, staggered work patterns must be encouraged, to reduce the numbers of people both in the workplace and in public transport.    Therefore, downgraded to 1G;   https://web.archive.org/web/20200715180019/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20200629224753/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/europe/macron-details-phase-3-of-deconfinement-in-france/1876966

True return to normal for almost all public transport in Paris and Ile-de-France. All metro stations will be open from June 22, 2020. Almost all RATP buses, tram, metro and RER are working at 100%. The same goes for the majority of Transilien SNCFs. https://web.archive.org/web/20200722155345/https://www.francebleu.fr/infos/transports/transports-en-commun-en-ile-de-france-toutes-les-stations-de-metro-seront-ouvertes-a-partir-du-22-1592483057

From June 22, the French government communicates that movements inside cities, between regions, in public transports etc. are allowed. There is no mention of 'staying at home'.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915102027/https://twitter.com/gouvernementFR/status/1276526016803020804/photo/1

Although travel to French overseas territories is more difficult and restricted, travel within metropolitan France is permitted and citizens may travel freely yet responsibly. Masks must be worn at all times. https://web.archive.org/web/20200701055822/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19

The Schengen space is open to a restricted number of countries since July 1. The list is updated every 2 weeks in accordance to the evolution of the situation in each country.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200916142106/https://www.cnewyork.net/2020/07/31/liste-des-pays-autorises-union-europeenne-aout-2020/

The official EU webpage says the following about quarantine:    "No compulsory quarantine for travellers from EU, Schengen area and UK. Quarantine when travelling to overseas and voluntary quarantine for travellers from the UK. Symptomatic travellers during border health checks should be subject to quarantine, regardless of their nationality."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200706170147/https://reopen.europa.eu/en/map/FRA

Started again 22 June: https://web.archive.org/web/20200722155345/https://www.francebleu.fr/infos/transports/transports-en-commun-en-ile-de-france-toutes-les-stations-de-metro-seront-ouvertes-a-partir-du-22-1592483057

Stadiums and racing tracks may reopen to the public from 11 July. There is an upper limit of 5,000 people per venue.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200927114257/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19    However, at the request of the Council of State which had been seized, demonstrations subject to the obligation of a prior declaration are again authorized. The participants must not be more than 5,000 and must respect the sanitary rules (physical distance of at least one meter between people, systematic wearing of the mask when the respect of this distance is not guaranteed, barrier gestures).  https://web.archive.org/web/20200916095459/https://www.service-public.fr/particuliers/actualites/A14105

In most cities, the 14th of July's festivities were cancelled. Gatherings of more than 5000 are forbidden, but firework shows were still on in some cities, in various locations to avoid the formation of crowds. https://web.archive.org/web/20200915143427/https://france3-regions.francetvinfo.fr/hauts-de-france/carte-14-juillet-covid-19-voici-feux-artifice-concerts-maintenus-nord-pas-calais-1852168.html

Since 20 July, it is compulsory for all people aged 11 and over to wear face masks in enclosed public spaces. Some local authorities (including Paris) have extended this to outdoor public spaces as well. There is a fine for not complying with these restrictions.     Since 11 May, it has been compulsory to wear masks on public transport, taxis, and private hire vehicles that do not have a plexiglass screen. Fines also apply for non-compliance.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200831205158/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/france/coronavirus

Tests are free and can be carried out without a medical prescription and on non-symptomatic patients since July 25, 2020. https://web.archive.org/web/20200915140317/https://twitter.com/MinSoliSante/status/1297149019739873280?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1297149019739873280%7Ctwgr%5Eshare_3&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linternaute.fr%2Factualite%2Fguide-vie-quotidienne%2F2489431-test-covid-19-publics-prioritaires-tentes-de-depistage-ce-qui-va-changer%2F  "Afin de faciliter le dépistage de la Covid-19, les tests PCR sont totalement pris en charge par l'assurance maladie et ne nécessitent pas de prescription d'un médecin". https://web.archive.org/web/20200915135127/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915135513/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/soins-et-maladies/maladies/maladies-infectieuses/coronavirus/tout-savoir-sur-la-covid-19/article/se-faire-depister-lieux-et-conditions

Travellers from authorised countries outside the EU must provide a negative PCR test, or undergo a test at the airport, or quarantine themselves for 2 weeks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200916140946/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vacances

Masks are still mandatory in all closed spaces  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915092101/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/masques-grand-public  and, from August 3, préfets can decide to make it mandatory at all times outside the home locally:   https://web.archive.org/web/20200915134412/https://twitter.com/JeanCASTEX/status/1290210634722729984?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1290210634722729984%7Ctwgr%5Eshare_3&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.france24.com%2Ffr%2F20200804-quelles-sont-les-villes-de-france-oC3B9-le-masque-est-obligatoire-en-extC3A9rieur  This measure has been implemented in various cities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915092204/https://www.leparisien.fr/societe/la-carte-des-communes-qui-imposent-le-port-du-masque-en-exterieur-02-08-2020-8362416.php
Nothing has changed with this policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200701055822/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19
Nothing has changed with this policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200701055822/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19
Nothing has changed with this policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200701055822/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19

Since August 14, several departments (i.e. counties) have 'turned to red', which means that local authorities can decide on restricting activities or closing certain businesses (bars, theatres, pools, markets...). The main departments effected are: The North, the Bas-Rhin, the Seine-Maritime, the Côte-d'Or , the metropolis of Lille, Rouen, Le Havre, Strasbourg, Dijon - the two departments of Corsica (Corsica- du-Sud and Haute-Corse) and Reunion Island.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915142813/https://www.rtbf.be/info/societe/detail_france-sept-nouveaux-departements-classes-en-zone-de-circulation-active-du-coronavirus?id=10577551  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915082254/https://www.bfmtv.com/sante/covid-19-quelles-mesures-les-prefets-peuvent-ils-prendre-dans-les-zones-rouges_AV-202009130122.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915085810/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/loisirs  Remote work is no longer "the norm" but simply recommended: "Le télétravail n’est plus la norme mais peut rester une solution à privilégier en cas de circulation active du virus." https://web.archive.org/web/20200915082351/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/retour-au-travail  Night clubs have not been allowed to open throughout the period closed.

Ban on certain countries maintained, with exceptions.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200916144926/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/coming-to-france/coronavirus-advice-for-foreign-nationals-in-france/

The policy has not significantly evolved, the list of non EU countries authorised is updated regularly in consultation with EU members. /web/20200916143049/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/le-ministere-et-son-reseau/actualites-du-ministere/informations-coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-les-reponses-a-vos-questions/article/coronavirus-les-reponses-a-vos-questions

All students and professors who return to school on Tuesday, 1st September will have to wear masks. If a student displays symptoms, a protocol on dealing with this will be in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200827221555/https://www.gouvernement.fr/sites/default/files/document/document/2020/08/presentation_-_point_de_situation_sur_la_covid-19_-_27.08.2020.pdf

The Tour de France started on August 29.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915143200/https://www.lemonde.fr/sport/article/2020/04/15/le-cyclisme-se-raccroche-a-un-tour-decale-fin-aout-pour-assurer-sa-survie_6036621_3242.html

In red zones, préfets can forbid gatherings of 10 or more. The department of Bordeaux has lowered the 5000-person limit for public gatherings (that are applied nationwide) down to 1000.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915082254/https://www.bfmtv.com/sante/covid-19-quelles-mesures-les-prefets-peuvent-ils-prendre-dans-les-zones-rouges_AV-202009130122.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915083726/  This measure was implemented in Bordeaux on September 14.  /web/20200915083726/https://www.francebleu.fr/infos/faits-divers-justice/coronavirus-a-bordeaux-les-rassemblements-dans-l-espace-public-limites-a-10-personnes-1600089898

- Access to overseas territories is restricted: all travellers must fill in a travel certificate and carry it at all times during their journey for derogatory travel to certain overseas territories (French Guiana, Mayotte, New Caledonia, French Polynesia, Wallis and Futuna).   https://web.archive.org/web/20200916135617/https://www.interieur.gouv.fr/Actualites/L-actu-du-Ministere/Attestation-de-deplacement-et-de-voyage  - Metropolitan France: Préfets can re-establish a 100km travel limit in red zones, but this measure has not been implemented so far. https://web.archive.org/web/20200915082826/https://france3-regions.francetvinfo.fr/nouvelle-aquitaine/covid-19-limousin-zone-rouge-se-rapproche-1873104.html

There are no restrictions for travellers coming from the European space, excepted the UK: 2 weeks quarantine required. Tests are mandatory for travellers coming from 'active virus circulation' zones outside the European space.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915083127/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vacances

Masks are mandatory in companies, offices, open-spaces since September 1.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915134648/https://www.latribune.fr/economie/france/port-du-masque-obligatoire-les-regles-a-connaitre-dans-l-entreprise-855789.html

Since September 3, classes and schools are closed locally when Covid cases get detected. https://web.archive.org/web/20200915080853/https://www.francebleu.fr/infos/societe/covid-19-deux-premieres-classes-fermees-a-paris-apres-un-cas-de-contamination-1599150031

"On September 3rd, the government announced a new fiscal package to support the recovery of the French economy (“Plan de Relance”). The plan includes measures amounting to about 100 billion euros over two years and focuses on the ecological transformation of the economy, increasing the competitiveness of French firms, and supporting social and territorial cohesion. About 40 billion of this envelope is expected to be covered by grants from the EU Recovery Fund."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201009030538/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    Original announcement by PM Castex: https://web.archive.org/web/20201009030648/https://travail-emploi.gouv.fr/actualites/l-actualite-du-ministere/article/france-relance-presentation-du-plan-de-relance

"Entering the French territory is no longer possible from other countries (than the ones listed above) unless for specific imperious reasons and for French citizens or people living in France."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200916144252/https://reopen.europa.eu/en/map/FRA

From Tuesday 22 September, 2020, classes are no longer being closed if only one or two pupils has been tested positive. Their classmates and teachers are no longer considered as "contact cases". This measure aims at diminishing the frequency of schools closing  /web/20200923080458/https://www.20minutes.fr/sante/2866611-20200921-coronavirus-partir-mardi-protocole-sanitaire-allege-ecoles

The 2021 budget for the national health insurance is 4.2 billion euros higher for COVID-19 tests, vaccines, and additional surgical masks:  https://www.lesechos.fr/economie-france/social/tests-vaccins-anti-covid-la-securite-sociale-va-provisionner-4-milliards-pour-2021-1247984

On 23 September, the government implemented new restrictions again for the care-facilities:  The government’s policy for long term care facilities for the elderly (in French EHPAD - établissements d'hébergement pour personnes âgées dépendantes) includes the following guidelines:  o	Strict hygiene measures (masks, handwashing, social distancing, disinfection,   o	Visits are allowed, but all visitors have to take a COVID-19  test or an antigen test 72 hours before the visit, and to fill in a COVID-19-related questionnaire to establish the risk of entering the facility.   o	Visits should only take place in outside spaces.  o	Limit visits to families to exceptional circumstances  https://archive.vn/9tpIa/image

A total closure of bars and restaurants in both the Aix-Marseille region and the French overseas territory of Guadeloupe was announced by Veran as well, starting from Saturday for 14 days. These are the two zones placed on maximum alert.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200926094132/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/europe/france-to-roll-out-new-measures-as-covid-19-surges/1983688

In accordance with the will of the President of the Republic, a new testing strategy is currently being deployed in order to "drastically reduce the delays" to better monitor the circulation of the virus on the territory, to be able to isolate and treat patients much more quickly. To achieve this, antigenic tests will be generalized in the short term, in addition to RT-PCRs, which remain the reference. More than 5 million tests have already been ordered and are made available to health establishments and ARS. These tests are CE marked and meet, according to the manufacturer's declarations, the minimum technical specifications provided by the High Authority for Health (sensitivity> 80%, specificity> 99%), which issued two opinions on the subject, the September 25 and October 9.https://covid-19.sante.gouv.fr/tests ).  Several screening campaigns have been initiated in universities, in particular for health students. This is for example the case in Ile-de-France with campaigns at the Faculty of Medicine of Sorbonne, Necker or even in a Nursing Training Institute in Paris. Other campaigns are being carried out in nursing homes to ensure screening of asymptomatic staff, particularly in the Occitanie, Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes and Ile-de-France regions. These campaigns are in progress and an assessment could be drawn up later. The ministry wanted to broaden the experiments and deployment channels across the country very quickly.  In addition, liberal health professionals (pharmacists, nurses and doctors) are now authorized to carry out these rapid antigenic tests, ensuring a large-scale deployment and closer to the population.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19

In accordance with decree n ° 2020-884 of July 17, 2020, the wearing of a mask has become compulsory in closed places welcoming the public.    In addition, decree n ° 2020-944 of July 30, 2020 provides for the possibility for the prefects, when the local epidemic situation requires it, to extend the obligation to wear a mask to all relevant places , that is to say - also say public space.  This is an essential protection measure, especially in closed environments or when there is a high population density (market, busy street, etc.). In addition to barrier gestures (hand washing, physical distancing), it is the mask that filters the droplets from sneezing, coughing, or even prolonged discussion.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19

La capacité de dépistage dans les établissements scolaires sera également augmentée, avec un objectif de 300 000 tests par semaine et des objectifs fixés par académie.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115103746/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    Testing freely available for asymptomatic people who are at particular risk from the disease.  La vaccination est désormais ouverte à l’ensemble des personnes appartenant aux catégories suivantes :  •	Les personnes âgées de plus de 75 ans (à partir de lundi 18 janvier).  •	Les résidents volontaires en EHPAD et USLD, qui sont vaccinés directement dans les établissements.  •	Les personnes âgées séjournant dans les établissements de santé et en services de soins de suite et de réadaptation.  •	Les personnes âgées hébergées en résidences autonomie, résidences services et autres lieux de vie spécialisés, ainsi que dans les foyers de travailleurs migrants.  •	Les personnes en situation de handicap, vulnérables, hébergées en maisons d’accueil spécialisées et foyers d’accueils médicalisés.  •	Les professionnels de santé (et autres professionnels des établissements de santé et des établissements médico-sociaux intervenant auprès de personnes vulnérables), les aides à domicile intervenant auprès de personnes âgées et handicapées vulnérables et les sapeurs-pompiers, lorsqu’ils ont plus de 50 ans ou présentent une ou plusieurs des comorbidités suivantes :  o	L’obésité (IMC>30),  o	La BPCO et l’insuffisance respiratoire,  o	L’hypertension artérielle compliquée,  o	L’insuffisance cardiaque,  o	Le diabète (de type 1 et de type 2)  o	L’insuffisance rénale chronique,  o	Les cancers et maladies hématologiques malignes actifs et de moins de 3 ans  o	Le fait d’avoir une transplantation d’organe solide ou de cellules souches hématopoïétiques,  o	La trisomie 21.  •	Les personnes ayant une pathologie qui les expose à un très haut risque face à la Covid-19 disposant d’une ordonnance médicale pour se faire vacciner prioritairement.  Les patients particulièrement vulnérables à la Covid concernés sont les suivants :  o	atteints de cancer et de maladies hématologiques malignes en cours de traitement par chimiothérapie  o	atteints de maladies rénales chroniques sévères, dont les patients dialysés  o	transplantés d’organes solides  o	transplantés par allogreffe de cellules souches hématopoïétiques  o	atteints de poly-pathologies chroniques, selon le critère suivant : au moins deux insuffisances d’organes  o	atteints de certaines maladies rares (voire liste sur le site du ministère de la santé)  o	atteints de trisomie 21.  Si vous êtes concerné, vous pouvez vous faire vacciner dès à présent dans un des centres de vaccination ouverts.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115113356/https://www.sante.fr/centres-vaccination-covid.html    Testing for people who do not meet these criteria is also available, but at a cost of about EUR 70 to EUR 100. Which however is covered by French Health insurance (“Sécurité Sociale”). So e.g. a US citizen who is not covered by French Health insurance would have to pay for the treatment individually.  https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Further confirmation that testing without symptoms is available (need to get an appointment via a website), but people who do not meet the above mentioned criteria are not considered a priority (implying it may take longer for them to get an appointment).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115121550/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage
No policy changes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115112656/https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A, C:    Previously coded policy is still in place in this period. By now, 318.216 have been vaccinated, out of which 10% are residents of care homes. The remainder are caregivers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities, but also firefighters, home helpers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities.  https://archive.vn/J7Rwn    So some members of the following groups have started receiving vaccines:  A Key workers  C Elderly groups  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    The vaccines that are given are PfizerBiontech and Moderna.  BioNTech-Pfizer's vaccine was approved by the EMA and then by the European Commission on 22 December. On Wednesday 6 January 2021, the European Commission gave the green light to the Covid-19 vaccine developed by the American start-up Moderna, this decision was approved by the High Health Authority on Friday 8 January 2021. To date, two additional vaccines are being evaluated by the EMA following Phase III clinical trials: the AstraZeneca and Janssen laboratories.  https://archive.vn/dNmaS    In addition, from 18 January, people over the age of 75 will be able to get vaccinated as well as people with one of the five pathologies leading to a very high risk of serious form of the disease, regardless of their age.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210113222447/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins    Note that the government has faced a lot of criticism regarding a perceived slowness and overly bureaucratic approach in rolling out the vaccines.  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    France wants to immunize 1 million people by the end of January but at the current vaccination rate, it will reach that target in late February.  There is also widespread vaccine-scepticism.  https://archive.vn/trhlh    Polls suggest that less than 40% of the population here is planning to take the vaccine.   https://archive.vn/J7Rwn

A,C:     As of February 5th, over 2 million vaccinations have given in France https://web.archive.org/web/20210207203851/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/actualites/presse/communiques-de-presse/article/vaccin-anti-covid-premiere-livraison-de-doses-du-vaccin-astrazeneca-ce-samedi-6    PfizerBiontech and Moderna are being administered, with the AztraZeneca vaccine available as of February 6th. Following approval by EMA on January 29th 2020, the Haute autorité de santé (HAS) approved the AstraZeneca vaccine for use with two groups: "people under 65, starting with professionals in the health or medico-social sector, whatever their age; and in people aged 50 to 64, prioritizing those with co-morbidities" per https://web.archive.org/web/20210207203851/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/actualites/presse/communiques-de-presse/article/vaccin-anti-covid-premiere-livraison-de-doses-du-vaccin-astrazeneca-ce-samedi-6    France24 reported that first doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine were administered to health workers on Feb 6 2021 at "The Hospices Civils de Lyon, which received 7,700 doses on Friday evening [...] began to vaccinate their nursing staff and liberal doctors on Saturday afternoon at the Édouard-Herriot hospital, according to their press service." https://web.archive.org/web/20210208213549/https://www.france24.com/fr/france/20210206-covid-19-premi%C3%A8res-injections-du-vaccin-d-astrazeneca-en-france    This addition will expand availability to Group B (clinically vulnerable groups), adding this cohort to existing Key Worker and Elderly groups that are eligible for vaccination. Although the first doses of the AstraZeneva vaccine were delivered to France on February 6th, injection of people will begin "As soon as the quantities delivered allow it, it can be administered by town doctors, then, subsequently, in local pharmacies, for people meeting the criteria required by the HAS (people aged 50 to 64, starting with those with comorbidities). The exact date of initiation of vaccination for these people will be communicated very soon, depending on the doses available." so coding remains as 2G, but should move to 3G in the near future.

Government guidelines are to:  - "Limit social contacts as much as possible (maximum 6)".   - "It is not possible to receive guests at home during the curfew. Persons attending this type of invitation will not be able to justify their travel by any of the permitted reasons for travel. They are therefore liable to a fine of 135 euros for a first offence and up to 3750 euros for repeated non-compliance with curfew rules."  - "Throughout the country, theatres, shows and cinemas are closed to the public. On the other hand, professional artists wishing to rehearse or capture can visit these establishments. In addition, all over the country, multi-purpose rooms and party halls are closed. They may remain open to a mission of general interest (welcoming a vulnerable public, blood collection, etc.). Libraries and archives are open to the public, in accordance with strict health protocols."  - "No, private rooms are not allowed to open to host such events. [Marriages, baptisms]"  - "Professional sports competitions can still take place but will have to take place behind closed doors, the reception of the public will be prohibited. Amateur sports competitions are suspended."  - "Throughout the country, gyms, casinos, gaming rooms, fairs and fairs will have to remain closed to the public."  - "Gatherings of more than 6 people on public roads are prohibited with the exception of demonstrations declared to the prefectural authorities, funeral ceremonies or patriotic ceremonies that will have to guarantee compliance with the barrier measures."  - "Attendance at a City Council meeting is not a derogatory reason for individuals to travel during curfew hours. Elected officials, on the other hand, can travel under the title of "professional travel."  The local executive may decide, in order to ensure that the meeting of the deliberative body is held under conditions in accordance with the current health rules, that it should take place without the public being allowed to attend or by setting a maximum number of persons authorized to  attend. The public nature of the meeting is deemed satisfactory when the debates are available live to the public electronically. If so, this decision on the convening of the deliberative body should be referred to."  - "Parks and gardens, as well as beaches, lakes and bodies of water, remain accessible if they are within the 20-kilometre limit around his home. On the other hand, it is not possible to gather there more than 6 people."  - "Places of worship are allowed to open and offices are allowed to be held there in accordance with a health protocol and an organisation allowing two seats to be left free between each person or family entity and to occupy only one row out of two. Civil marriages can take place in accordance with a health protocol and an organization that allows two seats to be left free between each person or family entity and to occupy only one row out of two."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212193900/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212193900/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

No change in policy - A national curfew between the hours of 6pm and 6am (8pm and 6am in some Departments) has been imposed since January 16 2021 for a period of at least 15 days, and remains in place as of Feb. 19. Most workplaces must close during these hours.     Since February 1 2021, non-food businesses larger than 20,000 square meters are closed. Bars, restaurants, cinemas, theaters, sports and leisure facilities, winter sports venues and nightclubs are closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219232808/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Religious activities are permitted with adherance to the following: "ervices in places of worship are permitted, the faithful must respect a rule of one seat out of three and one row out of two to attend."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219232808/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Government guidelines are to:  - "Limit social contacts as much as possible (maximum 6)".   - "It is not possible to receive guests at home during the curfew. Persons attending this type of invitation will not be able to justify their travel by any of the permitted reasons for travel. They are therefore liable to a fine of 135 euros for a first offence and up to 3750 euros for repeated non-compliance with curfew rules."  - "Throughout the country, theatres, shows and cinemas are closed to the public. On the other hand, professional artists wishing to rehearse or capture can visit these establishments. In addition, all over the country, multi-purpose rooms and party halls are closed. They may remain open to a mission of general interest (welcoming a vulnerable public, blood collection, etc.). Libraries and archives are open to the public, in accordance with strict health protocols."  - "No, private rooms are not allowed to open to host such events. [Marriages, baptisms]"  - "Professional sports competitions can still take place but will have to take place behind closed doors, the reception of the public will be prohibited. Amateur sports competitions are suspended."  - "Throughout the country, gyms, casinos, gaming rooms, fairs and fairs will have to remain closed to the public."  - "Gatherings of more than 6 people on public roads are prohibited with the exception of demonstrations declared to the prefectural authorities, funeral ceremonies or patriotic ceremonies that will have to guarantee compliance with the barrier measures."  - "Attendance at a City Council meeting is not a derogatory reason for individuals to travel during curfew hours. Elected officials, on the other hand, can travel under the title of "professional travel."  The local executive may decide, in order to ensure that the meeting of the deliberative body is held under conditions in accordance with the current health rules, that it should take place without the public being allowed to attend or by setting a maximum number of persons authorized to  attend. The public nature of the meeting is deemed satisfactory when the debates are available live to the public electronically. If so, this decision on the convening of the deliberative body should be referred to."  - "Parks and gardens, as well as beaches, lakes and bodies of water, remain accessible if they are within the 20-kilometre limit around his home. On the other hand, it is not possible to gather there more than 6 people."  - "Places of worship are allowed to open and offices are allowed to be held there in accordance with a health protocol and an organisation allowing two seats to be left free between each person or family entity and to occupy only one row out of two. Civil marriages can take place in accordance with a health protocol and an organization that allows two seats to be left free between each person or family entity and to occupy only one row out of two."    Details from the "Sur ma vie sociale" section of the "Questions/ Reponses" information provided at https://web.archive.org/web/20210219232808/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

"On January 14, 2021, the Prime Minister announced the advancement of the curfew from 8:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. throughout the metropolitan territory from Saturday January 16, 2021 for a minimum duration of 15 days. The objective of the curfew is to limit gatherings during which barrier measures are less well applied and where the virus circulates quickly while limiting the impact on the economy already strained by the epidemic. Outings and trips without a derogatory certificate are therefore prohibited from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. throughout mainland France, under penalty of a fine of € 135 and up to € 3,750 in the event of a repeat offense." For most of the country, there is no change to existing guidance. https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus     In the Alpes-Maritimes department and in the Dunkirk region, additional measures are being implemented in response to an increase in Covid-19 infection rate. In these areas:     "businesses will have to comply with new measures. In particular, these institutions will need to have a COVID referent responsible for ensuring the proper implementation of the barrier gestures. Controls on the implementation of barrier actions in public-receiving establishments and covered and uncovered markets will also be strengthened.    In addition, the attendance gauge in shops will be lowered. For businesses over 400 sqm, the gauge will be increased from 10 sqm per customer to 15 sqm per customer. Food shops are invited to advance their opening hours in the morning in order to further spread their attendance.    Shops, commercial spaces or commercial units (including distributed by outdoor aisles) of more than 5,000 square metres, with the exception of food shops, pharmacies (similar to shopping centres over 20,000 sqm) will be closed. However, from Monday 6am to Friday 6pm, these businesses will be able to continue to welcome the public only for click-and-collect activities and ensure deliveries. These businesses remain bound by curfew rules."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210227042501/https://www.alpes-maritimes.gouv.fr/Actualites/COVID-19-Point-sur-la-situation-dans-les-Alpes-Maritimes/COVID-19-Adoptions-de-mesures-complementaires and https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

The text of a speeches delivered by (Jean Castex, Prime Minister of France), Olivier Véran (Minister of Solidarity and Health) and Alain Fischer (Chairman of the Guidance Council of the Vaccine Strategy) on February 25th are available at https://web.archive.org/web/20210228031714/https://www.gouvernement.fr/partage/12128-conference-de-presse-sur-les-mesures-contre-la-covid-19-discours-de-jean-castex    Topics covered include:    - containment measures have been implemented in the overseas departments of Mayotte and Reunion  - that the areas of Nice and Dunkirk are experiencing infection rates 3 to 4 times higher than the national average, and that containment measures will be implemented  for the weekend of February 26th through March 1  - that epidemiological indicators in a further 20 departments are unfavourable (~250 cases per 100,000 population, accelerating infection rate, pressure on hospital resources), requiring implementation of enhanced surveillance and the potential for further containment measures to be implemented from the weekend of March 6th  - progress of the vaccination campaign

The internal movement restrictions announced for the Alpes-Maritimes and Dunkirk regions are not applied from the morning of 1 March through 5 March.

"During periods of confinement, all businesses located in this coastal area, with the exception of food businesses, pharmacies, medical analysis laboratories, service stations, tobacco shops and garages, will be closed. without the possibility of click-and-collect."   This seems to meet the threshold of closing all nonessential businesses during the period of confinement in these targeted areas.   ***Recoded from 2G to 3T.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210227042501/https://www.alpes-maritimes.gouv.fr/Actualites/COVID-19-Point-sur-la-situation-dans-les-Alpes-Maritimes/COVID-19-Adoptions-de-mesures-complementaires

From February 26 through March 1, and again from March 5 through March 8th, travel into and within the Alpes-Maritimes region will be restricted. Extracts from the requirements published by the Alpes-Maritimes Department follow:     - Partial containment will be implemented from Friday, February 26 at 6 p.m. to Monday, March 1 at 6 a.m. and Friday, March 5 at 6 p.m. to Monday, March 8 at 6 a.m. During these periods, travel not justified by one of the derogatory reasons will be prohibited. These derogatory reasons, which will be certified, relate to travel related to a professional activity or the purchase of supplies related to the exercise of a professional activity; travel related to the purchase of basic necessities; Travel for medical reasons Travel motivated by compelling family motives; travel related to individual physical activity and the exit of pets for up to one hour and within a 5 km radius around the home.  - The area affected by this measure extends over the coastal area of the Alpes-Maritimes  - As for the conditions of entry into the territory, they will be subject to strengthened controls, at the Franco-Italian border (road and rail lanes) as well as at Nice Côte d'Azur and Cannes-Mandelieu airports with the completion of PCR tests on all passengers of randomly selected flights.  - The internal security forces are fully mobilized to ensure compliance with these measures, as are the state services in charge of the control of trades.    Full details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210227042501/https://www.alpes-maritimes.gouv.fr/Actualites/COVID-19-Point-sur-la-situation-dans-les-Alpes-Maritimes/COVID-19-Adoptions-de-mesures-complementaires    ***Updated to add targeted weekend lockdown in Dunkirk: http://web.archive.org/web/20210314142725/https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/Covid-Weekend-lockdown-in-Dunkirk-as-UK-variant-spreads

"The whole of France will be placed under a limited lockdown for four weeks from Saturday April 3rd, President Emmanuel Macron announced on Wednesday (...) The partial lockdown was already in place in 19 départements, mainly the Paris region and parts of northern France but from Saturday April 3rd they will be extended across the whole of the country (...) The restrictions will be in place nationwide for four weeks, so if they succeed in reducing the infection rate and ease pressure on hospitals they could end on May 2nd.    (...) There are several aspects of this lockdown that have been slightly eased or altered, compared to the national lockdown in November.    (...) Non-essential shops are shut, but the definition of essential has been expanded to include hairdressers, bookshops and music shops, in addition to the businesses which remained open during the November lockdown." The nationwide night-time curfew remains in place, people must remain at home between 7pm and 6am with limited exceptions & self-certification required for those outside the home during these hours.     From 7pm on 3 April for a period of 4 weeks, the containment measures implemented in 19 departments have been extended nationwide. People are allowed to be outside within a 10km radius of their home between the hours of 6am and 7pm with proof of residence, but must produce a certificate explaining the essential nature of their travel if further than 10km from their residence.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404151725/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Lateral flow tests are available in French pharmacies from 12 April to anyone aged over 15, with the following provisions in force:  - For sale in pharmacies (not yet in supermarkets; online sales are banned) - Only to be used by people aged 15 and over without symptoms - Priced at €6 each maximum, reducing to €5.20 from May 15 - Not reimbursed except in the case of some vulnerable people or carers of vulnerable people - Any positive result must immediately be confirmed with a RT-PCR test - Anyone with a positive result must immediately self-isolate and inform their recent contacts  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412231033/https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/Self-testing-Covid-kits-on-sale-in-France-What-you-need-to-know  RT-PCR tests remain generally available to all, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic, with cost fully covered by health insurance per Government guidelines https://web.archive.org/web/20210418174122/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage

A, B, C:    AstraZeneca, Pfizer-Biontech and Moderna vaccinations are available per the “Data on COVID-19 vaccine deliveries” dataset issued by the Government at https://web.archive.org/web/20210418175238/https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/donnees-relatives-aux-livraisons-de-vaccins-contre-la-covid-19/    First availability of the Janssen vaccine in France is expected on 25 April, according to the above dataset, despite the Health Minister's assertion on 10 April that  "First delivery of the Johnson and Johnson vaccine is expected tomorrow [11 April] in France, a week ahead of schedule" (https://archive.vn/81gfC) it does not appear that this vaccine has been integrated into the supply chain yet.     From 12 April "From Monday, all over 55s can be vaccinated" https://archive.vn/81gfC, and in addition from 17 April, special vaccination slots would open for "priority professionals over the age of 55 (teachers, police, gendarmes, etc)". Per https://web.archive.org/web/20210418175137/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins groups now eligible to receive vaccines are:     - key workers  - 18-49 year olds with a very high-risk condition of Covid-19;  - 50-55 year olds with a very high-risk condition of Covid-19 or one or more comorbidities;  - people aged 55 and over regardless of where they live and health (with or without comorbidities);  - adults with disabilities, housed in specialized foster homes or nursing homes;  - pregnant women from the second trimester of pregnancy.

No change to policy implemented, strict controls remain in effect. In addition, stricter controls will be placed on arrivals from Brazil, Argentina, Chile, South Africa and India from 24 April. People arriving from these countries will have to provide exceptional reason for traveling to France, present a negative PCR test conducted within 36 hours of boarding the flight, perform an antigen test on arrival, and are subject to 10 day quarantine after arrival with fines between € 1,000 and € 1,500 for non-compliance. https://web.archive.org/web/20210423175146/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    The government announced plans on 18 April to expand capabilities of the TousAntiCovid cellphone application (https://web.archive.org/web/20210423183430/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tousanticovid) through the integration of notes showing Covid-19 test results and vaccination status. These capabilities will be used on an experimental basis to prove infection and vaccination status for people flying to Corsica, and if succesful may be extended to ease travel restrictions to other French territories, overseas departments, and within the EU. https://web.archive.org/web/20210423182739/https://www.lefigaro.fr/secteur/high-tech/pass-sanitaire-l-application-tousanticovid-va-certifier-tests-et-vaccination-20210418

"Only shops selling basic necessities are allowed to open - including bookstores, record stores, DIY, plant and flower stores, hairdressers, shoemakers, chocolatiers, car dealerships, real estate visits - in order to reduce contact in enclosed areas. Businesses that generate large population mixs and thus present a risk of increased circulation of the virus are closed throughout the territory. Thus, are affected by the closure:    - non-food businesses with more than 10,000 square metres of useful commercial space;  - non-food shops in shopping malls and shopping malls with a useful commercial area of more than 10,000 square metres.    To limit the concentration of flows and encourage commercial activity, the possibilities of opening shops on Sundays are widened and establishments are encouraged to take advantage of the opportunities for additional opening on the lunch break. All sectors still subject to administrative closures (bars, restaurants, nightclubs, etc.) or directly affected by sanitary measures will continue to benefit from aid measures." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210507204759/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    Updated guidance encouraging all business to maximise use of telework and minimise infection risk has been published at https://web.archive.org/web/20210507205725/https://www.gouvernement.fr/le-nouveau-protocole-national-en-entreprise-contre-la-covid-19

During his speech on 31 March, French President Emmanuel Macron spoke of a gradual reopening of these places, and according to a strict health protocol, from 19 May 2021." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210507204759/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

A nationwide curfew is in place between the hours of 7:00pm and 6:00 am, people are only allowed to leave their homes with a self-issued certificate explaining their need to conduct business trups, travel for medical consultations or vaccinations, compelling family reaons, if they are disabled or aiding a disabled person, travel to stations or airports for the purposes of one of these reasons, or within a 1km radius of their homes for exercising pets.     Restrictions introduced on day-time movements outside the home on 3 April were lifted on 3 May. The government published a timetable for further lifting of restrictions:     May 19, 2021: curfew postponed to 9 p.m. and reopening of shops, terraces, museums, cinemas and theatres with limited gauges;  9 June 2021: curfew at 11pm and indoor cafes and restaurants and gyms reopened; easing telework, in consultation with social partners at the business level;  June 30, 2021: curfew ends.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210507204759/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Work is under way to define these uses as part of the discussion of the draft law on the management of the health crisis. Certification may be required to participate in large gatherings of more than 1,000 people such as certain types of concerts or fairs, etc. From this perspective, only the QR code on the paper version of the certificate will have to be presented. Throughout France, return to classes for middle- and high-school students is taking place with students alternating between 50% in-person and 50% distance education. Coding remains at 2A, but under the legislation enacted on 28 May there is a gradual tapering down of unemployment support between June and September. In summary (and see https://web.archive.org/web/20210601133916/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/dispositif-de-chomage-partiel for complete details:     - until June 30, 2021 the rate of partial activity allowance of 70% for the sectors most affected by the health crisis activity (S1 and S1bis sectors) whose turnover suffered a very significant drop (80%) due to health constraints. These companies continue to benefit from 100% partial activity support in June, with no out-of-pocket costs for the employer, throughout the national territory. In this situation, the employee receives 70% of his previous gross remuneration (ie around 84% of the net salary) regardless of the size of the company (and 100% at the minimum wage)    - Companies whose activity has been interrupted by administrative decision due to the health crisis, or which are located in a territorial area subject to specific restrictions (...) when they experience a sharp drop in turnover, or which fall within the most affected sectors and which continue to suffer a very sharp drop in turnover, benefit from a rate of 70% until October 31, 2021    - For common law companies , the decree reduces the allocation rate for the month of June 2021 to 52%. On June 1, the remainder payable by companies in unprotected sectors increases to 25%.    - the rate of subsidy for companies of the most affected sectors by the health crisis is reduced to 60% for the month of July 2021, to 52% for August 2021 and 36% from September 1, 2021. The remaining charges for these companies will be 15% in July, then 25% in August and 40% in September. For the employees of these companies, the rate of the partial activity allowance paid to them drops to 60% of their previous gross compensation (72% net salary) from September 1, 2021.    Income support for the self-employed remains unchanged, described at https://web.archive.org/web/20210530143228/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/reponses-gouvernement-difficultes-independants

New regulations for entry to France were implemented on 9 June, with a system of green/orange/red list countries and different rules for travelers arriving from these lists, and exceptions for certain classes of traveler. Full details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210612160728/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19    In summary:     "Green List" - travellers from a country in the European area or from Australia, South Korea, Israel, Japan, Lebanon, New Zealand, and Singapore, are not subject to "compelling reasons" requirements for visiting France. Must provide evidence of a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before departure, OR proof of complete vaccination with an EMA-approved vaccine.     "Orange List" - from all countries not specified in other lists, must:     - all must present negative results of a PCR test taken 72 hours before departure or an antigen test taken 48 hours before departure  - vaccinate travelers not subject to "compelling reasons" test for entry  - unvaccinated travelers are subject to "compelling reasons", and must self-isolate for 7 days after arrival    "Red List" - travelers from a country listed in the order of the Ministry of Health identifying the areas of active circulation of the epidemic or the spread of variants (currently Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, India, Nepal, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname, Turkey, Uruguay) must:     - have a "compelling reason" to visit France  - negative results of PCR test taken up to 48 hours before departure  - mandatory antigen test on arrival  - mandatory 10 day quarantine on arrival, unless fully vaccinated in which case 7-day self isolation    The "Compelling Reasons" allows the following to enter France: French nationals, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their principal residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.

From June 9, the Health Pass comes into effect. Includes 3 types of documentation:  - certificate of negative test - a certificate of positive test of at least 15 days and less than 6 months - certificate of vaccination.   May be paper, or a digital version via the TousAntiCovid application.  The bearer must present their paper pass or QR code when entering an establishment or event that poses a risk of Covid-19 transmission, and will be notified if another visitor subsequently tests positive for Covid-19.   An orange alert is sent if at least one contagious and positive person was in the same place and declared themselves, requiring them to test immediately, to limit contacts and to monitor symptoms. On detection of a cluster, a red alert is sent with instructions to isolate and be tested immediately.  Use of the health pass is required to access certain types of venue, and events over specific sizes depending on location (indoor/outdoor) and type.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210612215746/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/tousanticovid-signal-cahier-rappel-numerique

In almost all departments within France, restrictions on public events were further relaxed on 30 June, with the following changes:     - maintenance of barrier measures and physical distancing.  - Health Pass required for outdoor and indoor events of more than 1,000 people.  - lifting of limits on the percentage capacity in establishments receiving the public.  - outdoor amateur sports competitions maximum of 2,500 people. Health Pass required for events with more than 1,000 people.   - resumption of outdoor festivals standing: 4 m2 per festival-goer. Health Pass required for events with more than 1,000 people.    However, people without health passes cannot participate in events over 1000 people. https://web.archive.org/web/20210624103643/https://www.gouvernement.fr/les-modalites-et-le-calendrier-des-reouvertures     Within the Landes department, the easing of restrictions is delayed until at least 21 July due to high prevalence of the Delta variant virus. Of particular note:    - Maintenance of the prohibition on gatherings, meetings or activities on the public highway or in the places open to the public with more than twenty people at the same time    - Maintaining the ban on outdoor festivals and events (shows, concerts...) with standing public and in establishments receiving the public  - Maintenance of the maximum limit of 5,000 people seated in establishments open to the public  - Maintenance of the obligation to wear a mask extended to high-density areas in tourist municipalities  - Maintaining the ban on the consumption of alcoholic beverages on public roads and in open-air public spaces in certain municipalities and also prohibiting the broadcasting of amplified music    https://web.archive.org/web/20210711132322/http://www.landes.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/communique_de_presse_-_point_de_situation_sanitaire_dans_les_landes.pdf

President Macron announced a series of future measures with the goal of encouraging vaccinations and slowing progression of the Delta variant. These changes include:     - mandatory vaccination for healthcare staff and care workers (to be approved by Council of Ministers on 19 July and Assemblee Nationale before the end of the month) from 15 September. It is proposed that unvaccinated workers will at first be prohibited from working in contact with patients and suspended from work for a period of 4 to 6 weeks to provide time to get vaccinated. If they refuse, a layoff or dismissal procedure can be initiated.   - Health Pass becoming mandatory to enter places containing 50+ people from 21 July, extension of use to restaurants, cafes, gyms, shopping centers, long-distance trains and buses, hospitals and Ehpad (LTCH)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210713160256/https://www.lemonde.fr/les-decodeurs/article/2021/07/13/passe-sanitaire-ou-sera-t-il-exige-quels-tests-seront-acceptes-les-questions-que-pose-son-extension_6088173_4355770.html    Additional measures announced:     - Specific vaccination campaigns will be set up for middle and high school students at the beginning of the school year.  - A booster campaign will be introduced for the first French people vaccinated from the first days of September.  - PCR tests will be made paying in the autumn except in case of medical prescription.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210713125310/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
