Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield, and Janssen vaccines are being administered.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210729185021/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Since 21 July, a new protocol provides in long-term care facilities for the elderly.  Measures for the protection of residents implemented are the same as in the general population, with additional safeguards including:     - It is no longer required to complete a self-questionnaire on arrival. The traceability register is maintained;  - Outings are allowed, without limiting collective activities on return (except in the case of risky contact), but maintaining screenings for unvaccinated residents;  - Day receptions are open normally.  - Visits by relatives can now be done without an appointment, in the room as in collective spaces. They will be organized in such a way that distancing is respected from other residents/families of residents. Vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail people (caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210729184634/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

No change to implementation of current policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20210729142134/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    On 28 July, new policy for middle and high schools was announced by the Minister for National Education, to be implemented from the start of the new school year on 2 September. Use of the Health Pass will not be required in schools. A four-tier system of restrictions will be in place with controls depending on the incidence of COVID-19. In summary:     Level 1 (Green): In person learning at all levels,   Level 2 (Yellow): In person learning at all levels,  Level 3 (Orange): In person learning at primary and middle schools, hybrid learning (alternating distance and in-person learning) in high schools  Level 4 (Red): In person learning in primary schools, hybrid learning for 50% of 3rd year, all 4th year and high school students.    Increasing levels of sanitary requirements, mask-wearing, restrictions on sports, and protocols for contact tracing will be applied at each level. The decision to trigger movement between levels can be taken at either national or department level.     Between 6000 and 7000 vaccination centers will be deployed in or next to schools alongside a campaign to encourage vaccination for children aged 12 and over.     For full details, see https://web.archive.org/web/20210729142325/https://www.gouvernement.fr/sites/default/files/cfiles/cadre-sanitaire-pour-le-fonctionnement-des-coles-et-tablissements-scolaires-ann-e-scolaire-2021-2022-91517.pdf     The Minister also noted that there are currently no plans to make vaccination mandatory for teachers, with approximately 80% of the profession already vaccinated – but that "This figure must go as far as possible towards 100% so that we do not have to go towards compulsory vaccination, this is the last resort. If the percentage of teachers vaccinated is too low, we will have to move towards that" - https://web.archive.org/web/20210729145019/https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2021/07/28/dans-les-colleges-et-lycees-les-eleves-non-vaccines-seront-evinces-s-il-y-a-un-cas-de-covid-19-dans-une-classe_6089766_3224.html

All business sectors admitting the public (e.g., cafes, restaurants, shops, cinemas) are now open in almost all of France, with targeted restrictions that were enforced in the department of Landes closing nightclubs, indoor standing concerts and outdoor festivals extended until at least 4 August - https://web.archive.org/web/20210725210808/http://www.landes.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/communique_de_presse_-_point_de_situation_sanitaire_dans_les_landes-3.pdf and https://web.archive.org/web/20210725210109/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    In Guadeloupe, a curfew is in place between 21:00 and 5:00 from 30 July - https://web.archive.org/web/20210729162842/https://www.guadeloupe.gouv.fr/Politiques-publiques/Risques-naturels-technologiques-et-sanitaires/Securite-sanitaire/Informations-coronavirus/Mesures-regionales-pour-lutter-contre-la-degradation-epidemique-aigue-de-la-4eme-vague    In Martinique, a lockdown is in place from 19:00 to 5:00. From 5:00 to 19:00, only travel within a radius of 10km is allowed from a person's home, with exceptions for travel to work. Teleworking is recommended, whenever possible. Discotheques are closed. Restuarants are only allowed to serve customers at outdoor tables, or provide take-away services. Restuarants and bars located in enclosed shopping cetners over 5000m2 are not allowed to open, unless only accessible from a public road. https://web.archive.org/web/20210729174015/https://www.martinique.gouv.fr/Politiques-publiques/Environnement-sante-publique/Sante/Informations-COVID-19/La-Martinique-face-au-COVID-19-mesures-attestations-recommandations     Similar restrictions will be introduced in La Reunion from 31 July - https://web.archive.org/web/20210729184634/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

In all departments of metropolitan France except Landes (see below), limitations on the number of people who can gather in public have been revoked as of 30 June. https://web.archive.org/web/20210716211324/https://www.gouvernement.fr/sites/default/files/contenu/piece-jointe/2021/05/dp-strategie-reouverture-annexe-v3.pdf    In the department of Landes, the prohibition on gatherings, meetings or activities on the public highway or in the places open to the public with more than twenty people at the same time will be maintained until at least 4 August due to high prevalence of the Delta variant virus - https://web.archive.org/web/20210725210808/http://www.landes.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/communique_de_presse_-_point_de_situation_sanitaire_dans_les_landes-3.pdf    In the overseas territories of Guadaloupe and Martinique, a curfew will be enforced between 7pm and 5am from 30 July for at least 3 weeks. Any gathering of more than 10 people on the public highway is prohibited with the exception of official ceremonies, protest events, sports competitions of less than 50 competitors and events without catering authorized by the mayors in their municipalities. Any participant in a concert, show, screening, meeting or sporting event must be seated and wear a protective mask for the duration of the event. Organizers will not be able to receive more than 75% of the capacity of the establishment. Use of the Health Pass is mandatory for all places where 50 or more people may gather (theaters, amusement parks, concert halls, festivals, sports halls, cinemas) https://web.archive.org/web/20210729174015/https://www.martinique.gouv.fr/Politiques-publiques/Environnement-sante-publique/Sante/Informations-COVID-19/La-Martinique-face-au-COVID-19-mesures-attestations-recommandations and https://web.archive.org/web/20210729162842/https://www.guadeloupe.gouv.fr/Politiques-publiques/Risques-naturels-technologiques-et-sanitaires/Securite-sanitaire/Informations-coronavirus/Mesures-regionales-pour-lutter-contre-la-degradation-epidemique-aigue-de-la-4eme-vague    Similar restrictions will be introduced in La Reunion from 31 July - https://web.archive.org/web/20210729184634/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Vaccination available to everyone aged over 18  and to adolescent girls between the age of 12 and 17, and to boys between 12 and 18 with parental permission.     From 15 September, vaccination will be mandatory for the following categories of people:   - All staff (including administrative) of health institutions, medico-social institutions (EHPAD, USLD, independent residences, disability structures with or without accommodation and including non-medicalized), social institutions attached to a health institution (LHSS, LAM, CSAPA, CAARUD, CLAT, CEGGID);  - Home help working with people receiving APA or PCH, in the context of home services or as employees of individual employers;  - The staff of medical transport companies (including contracted taxis);  - All professions in Book IV of the CSP, contracted or not, and professions for the use of titles, as well as their employees (e.g. medical secretaries, dental assistants);  - All health students;  - SDIS-Firefighters (professionals and volunteers);  - Occupational health service personnel.    Persons with a contraindication to vaccination will be exempt from the vaccination obligation. Unvaccinated personnel will have until 15 September 2021 to do so, or until 15 October 2021 if they have already received a first dose of vaccine, and present a negative test. A certificate of vaccination status will then be issued to them. Checks will be carried out from 15 September.    Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield, and Janssen vaccines are being administered.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210808165050/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

No new policy - continued from 9 June, with a system of green/orange/red list countries and different rules for travelers arriving from these lists, and exceptions for certain classes of traveler. Full details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210612160728/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19    In summary:     "Green List" - travellers from a country in the European area or from Australia, South Korea, Israel, Japan, Lebanon, New Zealand, and Singapore, are not subject to "compelling reasons" requirements for visiting France. Must provide evidence of a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before departure, OR proof of complete vaccination with an EMA-approved vaccine.     "Orange List" - from all countries not specified in other lists, must:     - all must present negative results of a PCR test taken 72 hours before departure or an antigen test taken 48 hours before departure  - vaccinate travelers not subject to "compelling reasons" test for entry  - unvaccinated travelers are subject to "compelling reasons", and must self-isolate for 7 days after arrival    "Red List" - travelers from a country listed in the order of the Ministry of Health identifying the areas of active circulation of the epidemic or the spread of variants (currently Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, India, Nepal, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname, Turkey, Uruguay) must:     - have a "compelling reason" to visit France  - negative results of PCR test taken up to 48 hours before departure  - mandatory antigen test on arrival  - mandatory 10 day quarantine on arrival, unless fully vaccinated in which case 7-day self isolation    The "Compelling Reasons" allows the following to enter France: French nationals, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their principal residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.

I have no symptoms and would like to get tested:  I can benefit from screening without a medical prescription, without even showing any symptoms. It is fully covered by health insurance;  I identify the screening center closest to me on the sante.fr site or on the site of my regional health agency, and I contact them to make an appointment;  I strictly respect the barrier measures and wear a mask when the distance of two meters cannot be respected and in all the places where it is obligatory;  I can also get self-tests at the pharmacy. The sensitivity of self-tests is less than that of laboratory tests, but these tests can be repeated iteratively. Self-tests are not reimbursed by health insurance.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210821190726/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage

The 2021-2022 school year begins on 1 September, with the Ministry of National Education, Youth and Sports implementing a strategy favouring in-person teachingattempting to limit the transmission of the virus in schools, colleges, and other institutions. Four levels of response are available for implementation depending on the prevalence of the COVID-19 virus within a region.     level 1 / green level       level 2 / yellow level       level 3 / orange level      level 4 / red level    with increasingly strict sanitary requirements, social distancing, mask-wearing and rules on attendance being enforced at higher levels.     Universities will be 100% in-person . Barrier measures will remain the norm and masks will be compulsory. If a student tests positive, they and their contact cases will have to self-isolate for seven days.    The "health pass" will not be required to access lessons in either schools or Universities, and can only be applied for certain festive, cultural, sporting and educational activities welcoming external participants or whose number exceeds 50 people.    Vaccination is open to all adults without conditions and to adolescents from 12 to 17 years old included. For middle school, high school and college students, specific vaccination campaigns will be carried out as close as possible to these audiences from the start of the school year.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210904054126/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

Use of the Health Pass is mandatory in all Departments of metropolitan France in order to enter establishments and gatherings where the mixing of the public is most at risk of contracting COVID-19. including (but not limited to):    marquees, theatre halls, sports or cultural performance halls, conference rooms;  trade fairs and exhibition fairs;  outdoor establishments including zoological, amusement and theme parks;  stadiums, sports establishments, swimming pools, gyms;  casinos, gambling halls and bowling alleys;  outdoor sit/stand festivals;  cinemas and theatres;  monuments, museums and exhibition halls;  libraries, media libraries (excluding university and specialized libraries, BPI);  sports competitions;  other events, cultural, sporting, recreational or festive, organized in the public space or in a place open to the public and likely to give rise to a control of the access of persons;  religious establishments for events not of a religious nature;  ships and boats, such as cruise ships;  discos, clubs and dancing bars;  funfairs, from a threshold of 30 stands or attractions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210915132113/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Domestic flights, TGV, Intercités and night trains and non-contracted interregional buses fall under the purview of this regulation, but other modes of transport, including public transport, are excluded from the application of the pass. https://web.archive.org/web/20210915132113/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Travelers from "Green List" countries (the European area, Saudi Arabia, Australia, Bahrain, Brunei, Canada, Comoros, Chile, South Korea, the United States, Hong Kong, Israel, Japan, Jordan, Lebanon, New Zealand, Singapore, Taiwan, Ukraine, Uruguay and Vanuatu.) may enter France if they:    - proof of having received all the doses prescribed for one of the vaccines approved by the european medicines agency  - OR the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) performed less than 72 hours before departure (less that 24 hours for unvaccinated people from the United Kingdom, Spain, Portugal, Cyprus, The Netherlands, Greece and Malta)  - OR a recovery certificate dating back more than eleven days and less than six months (this document is issued to the person who has been contaminated by Covid-19 on presentation of a positive result in an RT-PCR screening examination or an antigen test)    Travelers from "Red List" countries (Afghanistan, Algeria, Argentina, Bangladesh, Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Georgia, Indonesia, Iran, Maldives, Morocco, Mozambique, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Pakistan, Russia, Seychelles, South Africa, Suriname, Tunisia and Turkey) must:     - prove they are entering France for a "compelling reason"  - must present at boarding, the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight  - will be subject to a mandatory antigen test upon arrival  - will be subject to a mandatory 10-day quarantine,controlled by the security forces    Travelers from "Orange List" countries, ie all those not on the Red or Green lists, must:     - present at boarding, the negative result of a PCR test performed less than 72 hours or an antigen test (TAG) performed less than 48 hours before the flight. They may be subject to a random antigen test upon arrival IF they are unvaccinated  - unvaccinated travellers are subject to the regime of compelling reasons and will have to undertake to respect a self-isolation of 7 days.   - vaccinated travelers are not subject to the "compelling reasons" for visiting France    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210904054223/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

Vaccination is open to all adults without conditions and to adolescents from 12 to 17 years old.     Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and the Johnson & Johnson vaccines are available.     Booster vaccines offering a third dose of a COVID-19 vaccine (at least 6 months after administration of the primary complete vaccination) are recommended for people aged 65 and over, and people with comorbidities associated with increased risk of severe forms of COVID-19. A vcampaign is underway for residents of nursing homes and long-term care units (LTCU), people over 80 living at home and those at very high risk of severe Covid-19, and immunocompromised people.    Vaccination is mandatory for all those who work in contact with fragile people. From September 15, 2021, the following must be vaccinated:    - all staff (including administrative staff) of health institutions, medico-social institutions (EHPAD, USLD, autonomous residences, disability structures with or without accommodation and including non-medicalized), social institutions attached to a health institution (LHSS, LAM, CSAPA, CAARUD, CLAT, CEGGID);  - home helpers working with people affecting the APA or PCH, as part of home services or as employees of individual employers;  - staff of medical transport companies (including taxis under agreement);  - all professions in Book IV of the CSP, whether or not under agreement, and professions for the use of titles, as well as their employees (e.g. medical secretaries, dental assistants);  - all health students;  - SDIS-Firefighters (professionals and volunteers);  - occupational health service personnel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210925000754/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

In additions to protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers.     A vaccination booster injection is recommended for people aged 65 and over, and a booster campaign is underway for residents of nursing homes and long-term care units (LTCU), people over 80 living at home and those at very high risk of severe Covid-19 - https://web.archive.org/web/20210925000147/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Use of the Health Pass is mandatory in all Departments of metropolitan France to access cinemas, museums, cafes, restaurants, hospitals, retirement homes, medico-social institutions (except in case of emergency). From 30 September 2021, the "health pass" is mandatory for minors aged 12 years and two months to 17 years. https://web.archive.org/web/20211002230938/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Use of the Health Pass is mandatory in all Departments of metropolitan France in order to enter establishments and gatherings where the public is most at risk of contracting COVID-19. From 30 September, all people aged over 12 years 2 months must present a health pass for admission (reduced from 18). Venues include, but are not limited to, the following:    marquees, theatre halls, sports or cultural performance halls, conference rooms;  trade fairs and exhibition fairs;  outdoor establishments including zoological, amusement and theme parks;  stadiums, sports establishments, swimming pools, gyms;  casinos, gambling halls and bowling alleys;  outdoor sit/stand festivals;  cinemas and theatres;  monuments, museums and exhibition halls;  libraries, media libraries (excluding university and specialized libraries, BPI);  sports competitions;  other events, cultural, sporting, recreational or festive, organized in the public space or in a place open to the public and likely to give rise to a control of the access of persons;  religious establishments for events not of a religious nature;  ships and boats, such as cruise ships;  discos, clubs and dancing bars;  funfairs, from a threshold of 30 stands or attractions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161920/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Use of the health pass is mandatory to access places where people gather. The age limit for admission without a health pass was reduced to 12 years and 2 months from 30 September. https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161920/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire
